title: How Low-Income College Dropouts Are Getting Their Careers Unstuck
text:
Shawna Chen is a former intern for Politico Magazine.

When Zuli Vidal walked across the stage for her high school graduation, she was the valedictorian of her class and already enrolled in college a year early. But she was also the mother of a 1-year-old and she was exhausted from working a variety of part-time jobs. Choosing to accept a full-time job at the Citizens Bank to support her son, she tucked college into the back of her head and carried on.

But as the years went by Vidal found the lack of a college degree was getting in the way of her goal of creating a textile recycling and fashion company that employs people affected by human trafficking.

Story Continued Below

“I’ve been going through real-life stuff,” Vidal, 35, said. “I just kind of felt stuck.”

At the end of 2015, a friend suggested Vidal look into a program called College Unbound that had opened three years earlier in Providence, R.I. The program was designed to help adult learners who had some college credit but hadn’t earned a four-year degree; it remains the best path to a good-paying job—at least $35,000 for workers ages 25 to 44.

College Unbound in Providence, R.I., offers a chance for low-income adults who didn’t finish college to get a four-year degree. Students Dazanique Harmon, Kayla Gomes, Jennissa Perez, Andrea Romero, left to right, listen during a recent class discussion. Right, teacher Scott Weber leads a class discussion. | Jason Grow for Politico Magazine

“The traditional model—of having high school graduates transition into college in three months—doesn’t work for everyone,” according to journalist Jeff Selingo, author of College (un)Bound: The Future of Higher Education and What It Means for Students. “And for students who shift gears off that pathway, it becomes difficult, if not impossible, to get back on.”

That described Vidal perfectly.

“I was thinking like, OK, I work full time, how am I going to do this?” Vidal said. “But [my friend] had told me that they only meet one night a week, and that if I needed child care, I could bring my kids with me.”

Did you have a non-traditional college experience? Leave us a voicemail at (202) 922-6112 and we might share your story.

Story Continued Below

Every Tuesday, from 5:30 to 8:30 p.m., Vidal and the dozen or so other students in her cohort, most of them in their 30s, would gather in a classroom space at The Met High School—another initiative created by College Unbound founder and President Dennis Littky. After a quick dinner and casual conversation, students would clear the table to dive into their coursework. For Vidal, that often meant meeting with an adviser to discuss her fashion line and studying things like the four-step process of turning plastic bottles into recycled polyester fabric. The rest of the week was usually devoted to online classes.

Though College Unbound is open to all students with a minimum of nine college credits, its admissions policy prioritizes “underrepresented, low-income, adult learners with some college credit but no degree who are employed full-time in low wage jobs with little possibility of advancement.” Tuition costs $413 per credit, with a maximum of $4,956 per term. In contrast, undergraduate tuition, fees, room and board in the 2016-2017 academic year amounted to approximately $17,237 at public institutions, $44,551 at private nonprofit institutions and $25,431 at private for-profit institutions.

Before classes begin, students and staff meet for a meal and community announcements. Zulenis Liz, 2, attends the community meal at College Unbound with her father Valentin Liz (in blue) and mother Zulen Liz (not pictured). One of the benefits of College Unbound is that it provides childcare during the evening classes. | Jason Grow for Politico Magazine

“There are schools that focus on adults for continuing education. But specifically targeting low-income adults? Low-income working adults? … That’s the unique aspect of it,” said Louis Soares, the chief learning and innovation officer at the American Council on Education. Soares has been conducting a yearlong study on CU, to be released in October.

“It’s aligning a need,” Soares added. “For adult students whose identity is as focused on the role as a provider, family, or as a parent, you need to align your services, your purposes, your curriculum, your pedagogy, to that reality.”

Eighty-seven percent of all CU students graduate, according to Vidal, who now works as director of recruitment and communications for CU while continuing to pursue her fashion line. The CU degree—a bachelor’s in organizational leadership and change—requires at least 1.5 years, with most students graduating in around two years. CU has enrolled 135 students for the fall of 2019.

Ten years ago, when Littky first envisioned the school, “the college situation for low-income kids was horrible.” It still is. Sixteen percent of low-income college students graduate, compared with 58 percent of undergraduate students overall. Low-income students are also twice as likely to drop out of high school when compared with students from a middle-high income background, according to data from the National Center for Education Statistics. These numbers intersect with race and ethnicity, with historically higher dropout rates for people of color. In Rhode Island, only 50 percent of public high school graduates in 2009 earned college degrees within six years; the state has a lower completion rate than four other New England states.

“It’s not all the student’s fault,” Littky said. “It’s partly the college’s fault. College is all about, ‘We want our students to be college ready,’ right? And my mantra is: ‘Colleges need to be student-ready.’”

Top left: Dennis Littky is the co-founder and co-director of The Big Picture Company, The Met School and College Unbound. Top right: Vanessa Vigil, Community Outreach Specialist at Neighborhood Health Plan. Bottom left: Zuli Vidal, director of recruitment and communications specialist at College Unbound and a graduate of the program. Bottom right: Jose Rodriguez, a College Unbound graduate and currently the re-entry coordinator in the Prison Education Program. Rodriguez served time in prison before coming to the CU program. | Jason Grow for Politico Magazine

A year ago, the nonprofit college was granted “Candidate for Accreditation” status by the New England Commission of Higher Education. This recognition allows CU to apply to federal grants for financial aid, Littky said, which will benefit the 80 percent of CU students who are eligible for financial aid.

CU’s model could help other traditional colleges better support their students. One way to replicate the college model would be to create a structure that maximizes personalized classroom attention and meets the needs of nontraditional students while minimizing costs by using alternative facilities, like CU does, to house class meetings.

It’s got the “right engine,” Soares, of the American Council on Education, said. “The chassis feels right … . It seems like it has good legs. And if it can continue to recruit students and grow in that cohort-driven way, I do believe it has total resiliency and sustainability.”

Zuli Vidal, the director of recruitment and communications specialist at College Unbound, address students during the Tuesday night meeting. When she was a student, she focused on creating a fashion line to benefit victims of human trafficking. | Jason Grow for Politico Magazine

For her graduation day in December, Zuli Vidal designed her gown with the number 18 on the back, for the 18 years from the beginning to the end of her college journey. “I remember giving my speech when I was valedictorian in high school at 17 and looking from the stage to my son who was in the audience, and he was a baby at the time,” she said.

As she crossed the stage once more, she found her son again, now 19, holding her diploma. That same baby, a young man himself, presented Vidal with her certificate of achievement. “It was just full circle,” she said. “And it was a very emotional moment.”
